awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: Summit on Big Data and Cyberinfrastructure in Materials Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Materials science research is focused on development and deployment of new or enhanced materials to create value in virtually every aspect of modern life. Recent advances in data collection and application provide the promise of more efficient and novel materials discovery to accelerate creation and use of novel materials to serve society.  To realize the opportunities of such data, however, we require more open and integrated ways to understand and share information across the materials domain. 

This project is a community-based effort that takes a multifaceted approach to strengthening the Materials Data Infrastructure (MDI) core by facilitating direct action across the breadth of materials domain stakeholders. It fits NSF's priority to Harness the Data Revolution (HDR) as one of 10 Big Ideas to drive important aspects of the research agenda. HDR goals dovetail with the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) launched in 2011 to create a framework for government agencies to support research programs that build materials research data infrastructure. Nearly eight years into the MGI and as the community reaches to Harness the Data Revolution, we have an acute need to evaluate progress and develop specific guidance to help move the materials domain toward realization of its data-centric vision. Our effort is focused on how to bring centers of data creation into a unified vision to truly share data in FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable), functional ways to advance materials research. The project includes five, coordinated activities:
1.	Survey of current U.S. academic materials research data infrastructure and management practices.
2.	Education and promotion of FAIR data principles.
3.	Convening a summit on Big Data and cyberinfrastructure in materials research.
4.	Publication of a report of summit findings and outcomes.
5.	Creation of a Materials Research Data Coordinating Council.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Materials science research is focused on development and deployment of new or enhanced materials to create value in virtually every aspect of modern life. The most important, emerging science drivers in materials science center on applications of AI and specifically machine learning with the goal of accelerating discovery and deployment of novel materials to serve society.

The central goal of our multifaceted, cross-cutting project is to maximize the impact of the Materials Data Infrastructure (MDI) by connecting the community for integrated understanding and sharing of materials research data. The project is a community-based effort that takes a multifaceted approach by facilitating direct action across the breadth of materials domain stakeholders. It fits NSF’s priority to Harness the Data Revolution (HDR) as one of 10 Big Ideas to drive important aspects of the research agenda. HDR goals dovetail with the Materials Genome Initiative (MGI) launched in 2011 to create a framework for government agencies to support research programs that build materials research data infrastructure. The effort is focused on leveraging centers of data creation for immediate impact in creating a unified vision to functional data sharing developed by the breadth of stakeholders.

 

The most important, long-lasting outcome of this project is the creation of an organized, working alliance of all the stakeholders important to the development of a working materials data cyberinfrastructure called the Materials Research Data Alliance (MaRDA). This alliance is an instantiation of the MGI Strategic Plans conception of a National Materials Data Network. 

MaRDA is a direct outcome of consensus by Summit participants for an alliance to provide:

 • a forum for membership input on management of broader issues that may be beyond their individual scope or capabilities
 • a forum to support large-scale impact of outcomes
 • a vehicle to develop groups and support their work within the context of materials data stakeholders
 • a liaison to work with world-wide data alliances to coordinate and develop efforts and leverage existing expertise
 • a liaison to provide input to funders and high-level coordinating bodies
 • a forum to recognize and develop scientific opportunities uniquely facilitated by data-intensive approaches.

The organization structure is a grassroots organization (MaRDA) with an elected governance council (MaRDaC) for high level advocacy and coordination for cross-agency work.  A short meeting of ~30 materials leaders followed the Summit to clarify development of the Council. 

MaRDA is the glue that connects the materials data stakeholders. MaRDA provides the framework to coordinate existing efforts, but also to facilitate new efforts and get the actual, practical work done that is required to make valuable materials domain data resources more FAIR and realize the promise of the MGI.  MaRDaC organizes and facilitates MaRDA while clarifying big picture drivers and shining light on overarching issues and successes. 

MaRDA has held two successful Annual Meetings with membership now grown to over 300 individuals from the US and abroad.  MaRDA has become a centerpiece of the MGI National Materials Data Network convening working groups on a variety of topics identified by community stakeholders in open forums.  MaRDA has become a launching pad for coordination and organization of community efforts on FAIR data and Open Science including the new NSF Materials Research Coordination Network (MARCN).

 

MaRDA will have long-lasting impact by advancing community involvement in the MGI strategic goals of implementing FAIR data and associated infrastructure in materials science and engineering. This work will empower data-driven approaches including machine learning to accelerate the creation of new materials with properties that serve the needs of society in diverse sectors such as energy, sustainability, quantum technologies, agriculture, and healthcare.
